results.title: Making grass silage
results.creator_credit: Margaret Thomson, Realist Films and Great Britain. Ministry of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Shows methods used by British farmers for making grass silage. Covers the whole process, from mowing to use as fodder. Demonstrates methods of packing a silo, adding molasses, and ensuring proper temperature to mature the silage. Shows also use of a pit - an alternative device to a silo.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Thomson, Realist Films and Great Britain. Ministry of Agriculture

results.title: Making films that teach
results.creator_credit: Hal Kopel and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains how scripts for teaching films are prepared and how the films are photographed and produced. Emphasises the value of thorough and careful research in the preparation of educational film strips. The importance of cooperation between education collaborator and producer is also stressed. Illustrates different types of production - historical, dialogue, and location; also special techniques - timelapse photography, animation and x-ray photography. Prepared by the staff of E.B. Films based on 25 years experience in making films that teach.

results.title: Making films
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Lex Halliday and Avondale
results.brief_description: Shows the work done by filmmakers, following the process of filmmaking from scripting to finished print. Also shows many of the different uses of film. Commentary by Clark McKay.

results.title: Making curriculum relevant
results.brief_description: In this film, young people talk about the perceived irrelevance of school and a teacher explains a work experience program. Also, some teachers discuss what they can do to make the school curriculum relevant to the students they teach, especially in disadvantaged areas where school material often does not reflect the realities of the immediate environment.

results.title: Making cotton clothing
results.brief_description: Traces the production of a child’s cotton print dress, from the design stage to the pressing and packing of hundreds of finished garments ready for despatch to a retail store. Contrasts mass productions techniques in a garment factory to hand-made methods.

results.title: Making coins
results.brief_description: This film is a description of the making of coins in the Royal Mint today, with a brief historical introduction touching on some early British coins. Follows with a detailed tour through the departments of the Royal Mint from the melting house to the final inspection and despatch of the finished coins.

results.title: Making Chunky Move: C.O.R.R.U.P.T.E.D. 2
results.creator_credit: PAML, Angharad Wynne-Jones, Peter Hennessey and Erin Brannigan
results.brief_description: Making Chunky Move C.O.R.R.U.P.T.E.D. 2. is an exploration of how Chunky Move, one of Australia’s most exciting contemporary dance companies created this new dance work. It follows the company from the germ of an idea, to the stage, behind the scenes and beyond, with snapshot interviews with the key players, dancers, creative collaborators and other cultural identities as well as unique virtual 3D segments, sound bites and extensive footage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: PAML, Angharad Wynne-Jones, Peter Hennessey and Erin Brannigan

results.title: Making books
results.brief_description: The story of the mass production of books in the USA, showing the ingenuity and technology used at the Country Life Press, Garden City, New York. The film follows every process from the author’s manuscript to the finished book on the bookstall stand.

results.title: Making biscuit
results.brief_description: Making Biscuit shows life in a biscuit factory through the eyes and experiences of women employed in the blue collar industry. Four ex-employees of a biscuit making company were directly involved in making this film which was animated from over 2,000 slides.
results.description: Making Biscuit shows life in a biscuit factory through the eyes and experiences of women employed in the blue collar industry. Four ex-employees of a biscuit making company were directly involved in making this film which was animated from over 2,000 slides.
